awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Wireless Massive Access: From Fundamental Limits to Practical Design
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop theory and techniques for supporting densely deployed wireless devices. The project outcome will meet the urgent need for new wireless technologies enabling the Internet of Things (IoT) that facilitates important applications in healthcare, transportation, smart city, and public safety, to name a few. With limited radio spectrum, the key is to design an efficient system to support wireless massive access, where many devices are small and battery-powered. Specifically, this project will study the fundamental limits of wireless massive access under realistic assumptions and develop practical designs that approach those limits.

This project pushes the envelope of communications, information theory, and signal processing by studying models with a massive number of users beyond the existing theory for multiuser systems. This project will focus on two main technical challenges: 1. To develop a theory for communication systems in the regime of a massive number of devices. Important practical issues such as asynchrony and channel uncertainties will be addressed at the fundamental level rather than as an afterthought. 2. To design scalable codes that are resilient to various channel uncertainties. Learning techniques will be applied to exploit device idiosyncrasies to reduce uncertainties. Key design concepts will be evaluated through experimentation with software-defined radios.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview of Outcome: Our research has significantly advanced communication theories by focusing on massive access in many-user systems. We have developed methods for asynchronous communication, which are crucial for managing the complexities of dense IoT networks. Our approach reduces computational complexity for massive Internet of Things (IoT) deployments by showing that with logarithmic code lengths, nearly error-free massive access or neighbor discovery is achievable. We have introduced novel signaling schemes for asynchronous neighbor discovery, accounting for channel gain and delay uncertainties, enhancing system robustness. In the realm of mega-constellations, we have studied capacity and interference management, establishing both upper and lower bounds on capacity per unit area, which are crucial for designing scalable satellite communication systems. This work provides insights into how to optimize satellite density for maximum communication efficiency. Additionally, we have pioneered distributed learning techniques, reducing individual device load while improving system-wide performance. Our work on power control using deep learning methods not only optimizes energy use but also manages interference in multi-cell environments, pushing the boundaries of what's possible in terms of network efficiency and scalability. Furthermore, we have developed federated learning strategies that exploit channel and learning diversity, allowing for more efficient data handling at network edges. We have also crafted algorithms for continuous power control in multi-user systems, which outperform existing methods by leveraging real-time environmental data, ensuring adaptive and responsive resource allocation.

Intellectual Merits: This project stretches the boundaries of communication, information theory, and signal processing by focusing on models with numerous users, placing real-world channel impairments at the forefront. Our work offers new theoretical insights that will guide the design of future IoT systems.

Broader Impacts: Our research has broad implications for IoT applications in smart cities, homes, and public safety, contributing to the national push for a wireless broadband revolution. This could lead to rapid IoT infrastructure development, fostering economic growth. Additionally, our project supports educational opportunities for undergraduates, preparing them for careers in emerging tech sectors.
